chatgpt_double_star.new_statement: Policing should focus on preventing harm and solving problems, using the least force necessary and treating every person with dignity while protecting officers and the public. That requires clear, enforceable rules for stops, searches, and use of force; strong supervision and training in de-escalation, procedural justice, and crisis response; and transparent reporting with independent review when serious harm occurs. Communities should help shape priorities and measure results, while mental-health and social-service partners handle appropriate calls so police can concentrate on serious threats and constitutional policing.

chatgpt_double_star_rankings.new_statement: Policing should protect public safety and constitutional rights through clear, enforceable standards—especially on use of force—paired with rigorous training in de-escalation, crisis response, and bias awareness. Transparent reporting and independent civilian oversight should ensure consistent accountability while supporting officer wellness and professionalism. Communities are safer when police partner with residents and expand mental-health co-response and other social-service alternatives that prevent harm and reduce unnecessary arrests.

chatgpt_double_star_personas.new_statement: Policing should deliver safe neighborhoods and protect constitutional rights by using clear, enforceable rules—especially on stops, searches, and use of force—with strong de-escalation and crisis-response training. Independent oversight, transparent reporting, and fair, consistent discipline should be paired with practical support for officer safety and wellness. Cities should expand partnerships with mental-health, addiction, and social-service providers (including co-response teams) so police can focus on serious crime while residents are treated with dignity and respect.
